title: âš½ Origin Story
body:
Iâ€™m Oliver, but you wonâ€™t find a full name here. Not because Iâ€™m trying to be mysterious, but because this blog isnâ€™t about status or brand-building. Itâ€™s just me, sharing my thoughts on football.

I was born in Munich, Germany. My mother is Spanish. My father is English. And Iâ€™ve lived long enough in all three cultures to know that football isnâ€™t the same game depending on where youâ€™re watching it. I speak English, Spanish, and German, and each language gives me a different lens to read the game through, whether itâ€™s Marca hyping a LaLiga transfer, Bild dissecting Bundesliga tactics, or BBC reminding everyone of the magic of the Cup.

I grew up in a home where football wasnâ€™t really a thing. There werenâ€™t family allegiances or old shirts hanging up. I didnâ€™t inherit a club. No one handed me a scarf or said, â€œThis is who we support.â€ It was the school playground that gave me football, not tradition.

And that actually turned out to be a good thing.

Because without emotional chains or inherited rivalries, I learned to see football without bias. I learned it from the ground up, literally. On my own terms, through bruises, broken fingers, and every kid shouting â€œPass!â€ but never doing it themselves.

Football didnâ€™t come to me as a family ritual. It came as a blank page. And maybe thatâ€™s why now, all these years later, Iâ€™ve got so much to say.

title: ğŸ§¤ The Playground Goalkeeper
body:
I didnâ€™t start out playing football because I loved it. I started because I had no choice.

In school, if you werenâ€™t playing football during break time, you were basically invisible. Iâ€™d never played before, but every lunch break, there it was â€” a swarm of kids kicking a ball around, and nowhere else to go. So I joined in. And since I was new and had no clue what I was doing, I got thrown in goal.

Thatâ€™s how it usually works, right? You donâ€™t know how to dribble? Go in net.

But hereâ€™s the thing â€” I didnâ€™t hate it. I actually loved it.

I remember one day I broke my pinky finger saving a shot, and even with the cast still on, I was back in goal the next day. I didnâ€™t want to stop. The joy of being in that moment, stopping goals, making saves, being part of the game, it hooked me. Not because anyone told me football was important, but because it made me feel something real.

Then came Spain.

Visiting my family there was always special, but my cousin took it to another level. He was ridiculously good, technical, driven, fast, and I looked at him the way you look at players on TV. I remember standing there thinking, â€œHow does he do that?â€ And I wanted to learn.

One time, thanks to my uncleâ€™s connections, we got to train at Real Zaragoza. We were five, six, maybe seven years old, just kids, but there we were, standing on the same pitch as the first team. This was around the time they won the Spanish Cup, I think. It felt massive. The stadium was enormous to me. I didnâ€™t even know how rare that moment was back then. I just knew I wanted more of it.

Looking back, those early days shaped a lot.

Not because I was the best player, or even a good one. But because I played from instinct. There was no tactical understanding, no YouTube tutorials, no one telling me how to improve. Just raw joy, scraped knees, and playground rules.

And that goalkeeper? Heâ€™s still part of me. Even now that I play on the wing, Iâ€™ve never forgotten what it means to throw yourself at the game, literally and figuratively, even if it means a broken finger.

title: ğŸŸ¡ Dortmund vs the World
body:
Growing up in Munich, you learn pretty quickly that football is a religion. But thereâ€™s only one god â€” Bayern.

Everyone â€” classmates, teachers, neighbours â€” supported Bayern Munich. Youâ€™d see red shirts everywhere, hear the same names over and over. And me? I just didnâ€™t feel it. Not the club, not the dominance, not the smug certainty that Bayern were always going to win.

So I did what any stubborn kid might do. I went the other way.

Borussia Dortmund had something different. The yellow kits. The working-class vibes. The underdog energy. And more importantly, they had Mats Hummels â€” calm, classy, smart. He wasnâ€™t flashy, but he was solid. And as someone who was still playing as a defender, that mattered to me.

So I picked up my first kit, a Dortmund shirt, number 15, Hummels on the back, and I wore it proudly. In a city full of Bayern fans, that was basically blasphemy. But I liked being different. I didnâ€™t know much about the Bundesliga yet. I didnâ€™t know how good or bad Dortmund were. I just knew I didnâ€™t want to be part of the crowd.

At the time, I didnâ€™t realise how intense football identity could be in Germany. You pick the wrong shirt, and you get side-eyed for a month. But I was young, and I could get away with it. I was just the kid in PE rocking a Dortmund kit while everyone else wore red.

In hindsight, maybe that was one of the first football decisions I made entirely for myself. Not for attention. Not to impress anyone. Just because I liked how it felt. It wasnâ€™t even about hating Bayern. It was about finding a space for myself in a game that didnâ€™t feel made for me yet.

That yellow shirt wasnâ€™t just merch. It was a choice to see the game differently.

title: ğŸ® From FIFA to Football Fan
body:
Before I ever watched full 90-minute matches, I knew the names. Not from commentary or live games, but from FIFA.

My football education came through Career Mode. My first FIFA was 13, but really it all started on my iPod Touch. I remember sitting for hours, building squads, grinding training drills, and trying to max Fernando Torres out to 99 in every stat. I didnâ€™t play online much. Ultimate Team didnâ€™t hook me. What I loved was building something, watching players grow, and tinkering with formations. It was a private kind of football obsession.

And Torres, well â€” he was my guy.

He was blonde like me, Spanish like my mum, and played for English clubs like my dadâ€™s side followed. Every time I went to Spain, people would call me â€œTorresâ€ just because I was blond. It started as a joke, something uncles or cousins would say, but I clung to it. I didnâ€™t grow up with a national team to feel fully connected to, but Torres gave me something to hold onto. He became a symbol of both sides of who I was, and I felt proud of that. Watching him play made me feel like I belonged to something bigger, like there was space in football for someone like me.

He became my favourite player, not because of his stats, but because I could see myself in him. He wasnâ€™t just someone I controlled in a video game. He was a bridge between cultures, between childhood and fandom. Torres was the first player who made football feel personal.

Spainâ€™s Euro and World Cup wins in 2008, 2010, and 2012 just reinforced that. I watched them lift trophies and thought, â€œThis is mine too.â€

At uni, things changed. I wasnâ€™t playing football anymore, and I suddenly had time alone. No close friends around, no constant distractions. Thatâ€™s when Career Mode came back into my life. Hard. I played with every Premier League team, every Championship team, and I rebuilt clubs from scratch. Somewhere in that process, something clicked.

FIFA taught me tactics. It taught me player roles, formations, finances, and squad depth. I became obsessed with testing different systems, figuring out whether a 4-2-3-1 worked better for mid-table teams or how to survive relegation with a flat 4-4-2. I played Career Mode with every Premier League club and every Championship club, sometimes multiple seasons deep, just to see how different players developed.

It made me curious. Iâ€™d discover a player in FIFA and then look him up in real life. Iâ€™d build a team on the game and then want to see how they played on TV. In many ways, FIFA filled the gap left by not watching football as a kid. I wasn't raised on Match of the Day or Saturday broadcasts, but Career Mode gave me a way in, one that taught me how the game actually worked. That curiosity became habit, and habit became fandom.

Thatâ€™s how I transitioned from player to fan. Not by growing up in a football-crazy home, but through a console, a few spreadsheets, and a strange fascination with team chemistry sliders.

FIFA didnâ€™t make me love football, but it opened the door.

title: âš¡ Inazuma, Naruto, and Football Superpowers
body:
Before I had access to Sky Sports or BT or even stable match streams, my football dreams didnâ€™t come from pundits. They came from anime.

Every trip to Spain as a kid came with one secret highlight: Spanish TV. No Netflix. No Disney+. No Bundesliga packages. Just whatever channels my grandma had. And tucked between the cartoons and dubbed movies was a show that felt like it was made for me â€” Inazuma Eleven.

I couldnâ€™t get it in Germany. My dad had rigged our TV to get English channels, but Inazuma wasnâ€™t part of that. So every time I went to Spain, I was glued to the screen. The colours. The characters. The drama. It was football, but bigger. More emotional. More magical. And when I got older and learned how to watch anime online, I binged the whole thing.

This show wasnâ€™t just about football. It was about belief. About people who didnâ€™t care about the game being pulled into it by someone who cared so much they couldnâ€™t help but be moved.

Mark Evans, the main character, loved football like it was oxygen. And the way he convinced others to play, to try, to fight â€” I saw myself in that. I hadnâ€™t played 11-a-side until I was older. I hadnâ€™t grown up obsessed with watching football. But Inazuma made me believe that didnâ€™t matter. That if I trained, if I trusted my teammates, if I loved the game for what it was, I could still be something.

And then there was Naruto.

I collected all 72 books. Every single volume. I read them over and over. The idea that effort, friendship, and a bit of stubbornness could overpower destiny â€” it stuck with me. And when I found Inazuma, it was like those same values were re-skinned in football boots. It all clicked.

Even the DS games. I played them like they were life or death. Superpowered saves. Fire Tornadoes. Crazy combos. It wasnâ€™t real football, but it stirred something in me. Something bigger than tactics or results. It made me believe that you didnâ€™t need to have played from a young age to be good. You just needed to train, to trust your teammates, and to believe in what you were doing. That idea stuck with me. It made me feel like I still had time to grow into the game, even if I was starting later than most.

It told me I belonged, even if I started late.

Anime didnâ€™t just entertain me. It gave me permission. To be passionate. To train like I meant it. To believe that loving something deeply was enough of a reason to start.

title: ğŸŸ£ Discovering Villa

For a while, football was something I played, not something I watched. I didnâ€™t grow up tracking matchdays or club drama. I didnâ€™t follow a team. I just knew I loved being on the pitch.

But then I went to university, and for the first time in years, I wasnâ€™t playing at all.

Thatâ€™s when YouTube became my stadium.

I started watching Sky Sports clips, Premier League highlights, player compilations â€” just casually at first. But one video stuck with me. A match between Manchester United and Aston Villa. Jack Grealish picked up the ball on the left wing, dribbled in, and smashed it into the top corner. Not just the top corner â€” the kind of top corner you never forget. The kind of shot that lives in your head for years.

That goal changed everything for me.

It was electric. Confident. Raw. I didnâ€™t know much about Grealish, or Villa, or United. But I knew I wanted to see more of that. I started following Grealish, then Villa. Watching more games. Reading match reports. Following results. And before long, it wasnâ€™t about Grealish anymore.

Thatâ€™s when I realised I wasnâ€™t following a player. I was supporting a club.

It helped that Villa were growing. Every season felt like a step forward. I remember watching Dean Smithâ€™s team and getting attached. I remember wondering why Jacob Ramsey kept getting picked, only to watch him blossom into one of my favourite players. I started learning how club football works, how confidence builds, how systems develop, how youth players arenâ€™t just chosen on talent but on trust.

And the weird thing? I had no connection to Birmingham. No family ties. No local pride. I lived nowhere near the club. But Villa still felt like mine.

I came into football not through legacy, but through curiosity. Not through geography, but through instinct. I didnâ€™t grow up reciting chants or memorising kits. I grew into the game from the outside, by watching, thinking, and feeling.

title: ğŸ‹ï¸ The COVID Bootcamp
body:
When I dropped out of uni and moved back to Germany, I wasnâ€™t planning to go pro. I just wanted clarity. Space. A fresh start. But what I didnâ€™t expect was that Iâ€™d fall into one of the most intense football phases of my life â€” and all during a global lockdown.

COVID shut everything down, but for me and my best friend at the time, it opened a door.

We decided, in the most chaotic and sincere way, to train like professionals. Not because we thought we had the talent â€” we were both average at best â€” but because we had time, we had passion, and we had each other. There was a park nearby. We had no excuses.

So we made a plan.  
I bought us gear.  
We started running leap tests, doing passing drills, dribbling circuits, sprint intervals.  
No coaches. No expectations. Just effort.

And something wild happened â€” I got good.

I was already pretty athletic, but that stretch of time changed my whole game. I went from right back in high school to winger. I learned how to glide with the ball. How to move with purpose. How to attack defenders instead of just marking them. I wasnâ€™t just playing anymore, I was expressing myself.

We trained almost every day. And on Sundays, weâ€™d show up for amateur 11-a-side games. For the first time in my life, I understood what players went through physically. The fitness, the decision-making, the mental fatigue. Watching football after that became totally different. You see the game with new eyes when your lungs have burned the way theirs do.

And no, I wasnâ€™t scouted. No one came calling. But that wasnâ€™t the point.

That bootcamp and that COVID bubble was for me. It was proof that love for the game doesnâ€™t need a stage. Transformation doesnâ€™t need a contract. You just need a ball, a friend who believes in it too, and enough stubbornness to show up when the worldâ€™s telling you to do nothing.

That chapter ended when life restarted. I moved again. The training slowed. But the confidence and joy I found in those months â€” that hasnâ€™t gone anywhere.

title: ğŸ”„ Rediscovering Football in England
body:
After all that momentum â€” the bootcamp, the 11-a-side games, the pure rhythm of football in Germany â€” life happened. I moved back to England.

And everything justâ€¦ slowed down.

I didnâ€™t play for a year. I was living with my parents again, this time by the coast in a small town. The vibe was completely different. Quiet. Beautiful. But not buzzing. No teammates. No training. No park around the corner where someone always had a ball. It felt like I had pressed pause on something that was just starting to get good.

Even though Iâ€™m English on paper, at first I felt like a guest. I didnâ€™t understand how to join a local club, how people talked about football, or what it meant to belong here. Germany made sense to me. It was simple â€” you found a team online, you showed up, and you played. In England, everything felt harder to access, like there was an invisible rulebook I hadnâ€™t been given.

Then came a job opportunity.

I moved. Started fresh again. New place. New people. New version of me. And without knowing it, this job would give me exactly what I was missing: football.

It gave me teammates again. It reminded me what it felt like to create space, beat someone on the wing, shout for the pass. It made me feel like myself.

At the same time, something else was shifting.

I started feeling more at ease living in England. Iâ€™d always been English on paper, sure, but culturally, I still felt a bit like a guest. Everything had been unfamiliar â€” how clubs worked, how casual conversations went, how people lived and watched football. Germany made sense to me. England took longer. But now, with football in my weekly routine, something clicked. I started to feel more grounded. More open to exploring.

And thatâ€™s when I finally started going to games.

I saw Villa Park for the first time â€” even if just from the outside. And it hit me. This club that had lived in my head, on my screens, in my FIFA saves and post-match articles â€” now it was real. It was right there.

I hadnâ€™t even gone to a match yet. But I already felt like Iâ€™d arrived.

title: ğŸŸï¸ My First Villa Game
body:
Thereâ€™s something different about your first time at a stadium for your club.

Iâ€™ll take you to a match.â€ He said yes. And suddenly, it was happening. My first ever Aston Villa game. At Villa Park. And I wouldnâ€™t be going alone.

It was the 2024â€“25 season. Villa were flying high. John DurÃ¡n was on fire. The buzz around the club was electric. I didnâ€™t know what kind of game Iâ€™d get, but I just wanted to be there. That alone felt like enough.

And then everything changed.

Ollie Watkins equalised. The crowd erupted. My heart did too. I canâ€™t even remember the second goal clearly, it felt like it came instantly, as if the universe just blinked and we were level. And then DurÃ¡n stepped onto the pitch.

title: ğŸš¨ The Tottenham Incident
body:
After my first Villa match, I felt unstoppable. Like I had unlocked a new level of football fandom â€” the live match level. And living near London meant I had access to even more. More games. More teams. More chances to witness football up close.

So when my Liverpool-supporting friend floated the idea of catching a match at Tottenham, I was in. Then a colleague mentioned wanting to see Liverpool vs. Manchester United. Suddenly, I had plans for two high-stakes, high-drama games. And somehow, both came through.

The first was Tottenham vs. United â€” a wild 4â€“3 banger in the Carabao Cup, with chaos from start to finish. The second, just days later, was Tottenham vs. Liverpool. Also madness. I think it ended something like 6â€“3. And across those two matches, I saw more than ten goals. It felt like football had just decided to show off for me.

I had great seats. I got to see players I admired, like Son, who Iâ€™ve always loved watching even though thereâ€™s no Villa connection. It was pure football joyâ€¦ until it wasnâ€™t.

See, we didnâ€™t buy away-end tickets. We didnâ€™t really think about it. We just got what was available, and that landed us smack in the Tottenham home section. My Liverpool friend didnâ€™t wear colours, thankfully. But he did start celebrating when Liverpool went 3â€“0 up.

And thatâ€™s when it turned.

People around us started murmuring. Then shouting. â€œHeâ€™s a Liverpool fan!â€ â€œGet him out!â€ One guy wouldnâ€™t let it go. He kept turning around, raising his voice, pointing, threatening to call stewards. And all of this, with his 10-year-old son sitting next to him.

We stayed quiet, hoping it would blow over. But the guy got louder. Aggressive. The tension was real. People started looking. That weird, dangerous football energy you hope youâ€™ll never feel â€” it was in the air.

So I snapped.

I told him to chill. Asked what kind of example he was setting. Reminded him I was in a Tottenham shirt, which, thankfully, I had bought earlier that day just for the occasion, like a tourist. That shirt saved us. I leaned into it. â€œCome on, you Spurs,â€ I said. â€œWhat are you talking about? This guyâ€™s just a friend.â€

It worked. The guy backed down. Maybe it was the shirt. Maybe it was the confrontation. Either way, we stayed. But for a moment, it felt like we might not make it out unbothered.

That moment taught me something important.

Football is beautiful, but tribal. Passionate, but sometimes right on the edge. You can love the game, love the players, buy a shirt, pay for a seat â€” and still be seen as an outsider.

And in that weird, terrifying, adrenaline-soaked moment, I realised something else too:

That Tottenham shirt I wore wasnâ€™t just merch. It was armour.

title: ğŸŒ The Way I See Football
